title.narrative: ELIMINATING VIOLENCE AGAINST CHILDREN

description.narrative: Output 2.1: Greater awareness of the risks and long-term social and economic costs of VAC results in increased public demand for â€˜zero tolerance' policies, reporting of cases and enforcement of legislation protecting children from violence., which contributes to Gender Discriminatory Roles And Practices, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid), Violence, Exploitation And Abuse. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 2: Children, especially those in difficult life circumstances, suffer, witness and practice less psychological and physical maltreatment, including all forms of harm, abuse, neglect, and exploitation at home, in school, in care, in custody and in public spaces.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 2.1: Greater awareness of the risks and long-term social and economic costs of VAC results in increased public demand for?zero tolerance? policies, reporting of cases and enforcement of legislation protecting children from violence.

description.narrative: Addressing violence against women and children remained one of the key priorities of the family and gender policy of Kazakhstan. The Government of Kazakhstan accepted the Universal Periodic Review recommendation to explicitly prohibit corporal punishment of children in national legislation and continued strengthening prevention and protection of women and children from violence in the new draft Law ‘On Prevention of Family Domestic Violence’. UNICEF’s work on social norms on zero tolerance to VAC and parenting programmes contributed to the increase inpublic demand for policy changes. | Status:Met | As-of Date:18/01/2021

% of general public adults and child protection and justice specialists who agree that children who experience violence in the family are at-risk of developing long-term physical and mental problems(57920)

baseline.value: 59.8% of general public adults and 73% of child protection and justice specialists agree that children who experience violence in the family are at-risk of developing long-term physical and mental pro

target.value: 2020:70% of general public adults and 80% of child protection and justice specialists agree that children who experience violence in the family are at-risk of developing long-term physical and mental probl

actual.value: 2020:54.9% of general public adults and 70.5% of child protection and justice specialists agree that children who experience violence in the family are at-risk of developing long-term physical and mental problems
